author: phabc
content: Why not let the miners build the witnesses as they build the block? Cost is non-deterministic for users, but that's already the case with gas and hence why we use a `gasLimit` instead of an exact gas amount.

author: phabc
content: Miners would need to stay stateful, but I really don't think that's important because miners/validators are already assumed to be well capitalized.

author: ajsutton
content: Hmm Iâ€™m not sure thatâ€™s true. A lot of stakers are finding it very hard to run a full eth1 node because of the disk requirements. And if they have to stay fully Stateful state growth rates remain a massive problem limiting scalability.

author: phabc
content: I mean, stakers need to have ~$60k of capital locked at their disposition, possibly at lot more in the future. I don't think a $1-2k setup is much to ask / expect

author: phabc
content: Imo scaling nodes is a lot more important than scaling miners/stakers and seems like asking users to come-up with the witnesses is a recipe for ux disaster and end up with a lot more gas wasted on failed txs, which everyone will pay for.

author: ajsutton
content:
One of the aims is that stakers can run on fairly modest hardware so that staking is accessible.

It might be a reasonable stepping stone but stakers have to be across all shards so itâ€™s exceptionally limiting for scalability if they have to hold all state. 

Might be solutions and different trade offs - I didnâ€™t mean to reject the option but wanted to push back on the assumption that it wouldnâ€™t be a burden for them. It would definitely have a major impact on the current set of stakers we have.

author: phabc
content: No worries, I understand the concern. My main concern is user experience and predictability and I can guarantee that devs and users will be very vocal if witnesses need to be generated by the client. It would make interacting with protocols like Uniswap pretty much impossible since everyone interacts with the same storage slots.

author: phabc
content: This is imo a much bigger problem than requiring stakers and miners to have slightly better hardware than regular nodes.

author: phabc
content: Doesn't requiring clients to generate the witnesses also pushes a burden for people to store all the state? Seems like this approach will require the need of an additional layer of state provider service for clients to consume, otherwise the clients need to store a bunch of state.

author: phabc
content: And if such services are expected / needed for clients to generate witnesses, why couldn't miners/validators with lower tier hardware rely on these services instead if miners were to generate the witnesses?
